earthquake.summary: Drop, Cover, and Hold On during earthquakes.
instructions: If indoors, immediately drop to your hands and knees to prevent being knocked down.
Take cover under a sturdy table or desk and hold on with one hand.
Stay away from windows, mirrors, and heavy objects that can fall.
If outdoors, move to an open area away from buildings, trees, and power lines.
If in a vehicle, pull over to a clear location and stop. Stay inside with seatbelt fastened.
After shaking stops, evacuate the building carefully and watch for aftershocks.
Check for injuries and call emergency services if needed.
Be prepared for aftershocks which can be as strong as the initial earthquake.

flood.summary: Move to higher ground immediately and avoid flood waters.
instructions: Never walk or drive through flood waters. Just 6 inches of moving water can knock you down.
Move to higher ground immediately if you see rising water.
Listen to emergency broadcasts and follow evacuation orders from local authorities.
Disconnect electrical appliances and turn off utilities if safe to do so.
If trapped in a building, go to the highest floor and call for help.
Avoid contact with flood water as it may be contaminated.
Do not return to flooded areas until authorities declare it safe.
Keep emergency supplies including food, water, and medications ready.

hurricane.summary: Evacuate if ordered and take shelter in a sturdy building.
instructions: Listen to local weather reports and emergency broadcasts for evacuation orders.
If evacuation is ordered, leave immediately and follow designated evacuation routes.
If staying, go to an interior room on the lowest floor away from windows.
Board up windows with plywood or use storm shutters.
Secure outdoor objects that could become projectiles in high winds.
Fill bathtubs and containers with water for drinking and sanitation.
Have a battery-powered radio and flashlights ready.
Stay indoors during the storm and do not go outside until authorities say it's safe.

wildfire.summary: Evacuate immediately and protect yourself from smoke.
instructions: Evacuate immediately if ordered by authorities or if you feel unsafe.
Close all windows and doors to prevent smoke from entering.
Turn off air conditioning and fans to avoid drawing in outside air.
Wet down your roof and surrounding vegetation if time permits.
Wear protective clothing and a mask to reduce smoke inhalation.
Follow evacuation routes and avoid areas with heavy smoke.
Do not return home until authorities declare it safe.
Have an emergency kit ready with important documents and medications.

tornado.summary: Take immediate shelter in the lowest, most interior room.
instructions: Go to the lowest floor of a sturdy building immediately.
Take shelter in a small, windowless interior room like a closet or bathroom.
Get under a sturdy piece of furniture and cover your head and neck.
If in a mobile home, evacuate to a nearby sturdy building or storm shelter.
If caught outside, lie flat in a low-lying area and cover your head.
Stay away from windows, doors, and outside walls.
Listen to weather radio or local news for tornado warnings.
After the tornado passes, check for injuries and call for help if needed.

tsunami.summary: Move to higher ground immediately when tsunami warning is issued.
instructions: If you feel an earthquake near the coast, move to higher ground immediately.
Listen to tsunami warnings and evacuation orders from local authorities.
Move inland and to higher ground as quickly as possible.
Do not wait for official evacuation orders if you feel the ground shake.
If you cannot get to higher ground, go to the upper floors of a sturdy building.
Stay away from beaches and low-lying coastal areas.
Do not return to coastal areas until authorities declare it safe.
Be prepared for multiple waves as tsunamis come in a series.

blizzard.summary: Stay indoors and prepare for extended power outages.
instructions: Stay indoors and avoid unnecessary travel during blizzard conditions.
If you must go outside, dress in layers and cover exposed skin.
Keep emergency supplies including food, water, and medications for several days.
Have alternative heating sources ready in case of power outages.
Keep your phone charged and have a battery-powered radio.
Check on elderly neighbors and family members.
If trapped in your car, stay inside and run the engine periodically for heat.
Clear snow from vents to prevent carbon monoxide poisoning.

drought.summary: Conserve water and prepare for water restrictions.
instructions: Follow local water conservation guidelines and restrictions.
Fix any leaks in your home immediately to prevent water waste.
Use water-efficient appliances and fixtures.
Collect rainwater for non-potable uses like watering plants.
Plant drought-resistant vegetation in your garden.
Have emergency water storage of at least one gallon per person per day.
Monitor local water quality reports during drought conditions.
Support community water conservation efforts and programs.

heatwave.summary: Stay cool and hydrated during extreme heat conditions.
instructions: Stay indoors in air-conditioned spaces as much as possible.
Drink plenty of water and avoid alcoholic or caffeinated beverages.
Wear lightweight, light-colored, and loose-fitting clothing.
Take cool showers or baths to lower your body temperature.
Never leave children or pets in parked vehicles.
Check on elderly neighbors and family members regularly.
Avoid strenuous activities during the hottest parts of the day.
Know the signs of heat exhaustion and heat stroke.

power outage.summary: Preserve food and use alternative lighting safely.
instructions: Keep refrigerator and freezer doors closed to preserve food.
Use flashlights or battery-powered lanterns instead of candles.
Turn off or unplug electrical equipment to prevent damage from power surges.
Use generators outdoors and away from windows to prevent carbon monoxide poisoning.
Keep your phone charged and have a battery-powered radio.
Check on neighbors, especially elderly or vulnerable individuals.
Report power outages to your utility company.
Have emergency supplies including food, water, and medications ready.

gas leak.summary: Evacuate immediately and call emergency services.
instructions: If you smell gas, evacuate the building immediately.
Do not use any electrical switches, phones, or appliances.
Do not light matches or create any sparks.
Call emergency services from outside the building.
Do not return to the building until authorities declare it safe.
If you can safely do so, turn off the main gas valve.
Warn others in the area about the potential gas leak.
Stay upwind of the building if possible.

evacuation.summary: Follow evacuation orders and go to designated safe locations.
instructions: Follow evacuation orders from local authorities immediately.
Take your emergency kit with important documents and medications.
Follow designated evacuation routes and avoid shortcuts.
Inform family and friends of your evacuation plans and destination.
If you have pets, take them with you or make arrangements for their care.
Turn off utilities if instructed to do so by authorities.
Lock your home and secure it before leaving.
Go to designated emergency shelters or stay with family/friends outside the danger zone.

cyclone.summary: Take shelter immediately and prepare for strong winds and heavy rain.
instructions: Listen to weather warnings from IMD (India Meteorological Department) and local authorities.
If evacuation is ordered, leave immediately and follow designated routes.
If staying, go to the strongest part of your house away from windows.
Secure all loose objects outside that could become projectiles.
Fill containers with clean drinking water and store emergency food supplies.
Turn off gas and electricity if instructed by authorities.
Stay indoors during the cyclone and do not venture outside.
After the cyclone passes, avoid downed power lines and flooded areas.
Contact family members to inform them of your safety status.

monsoon.summary: Prepare for heavy rainfall and potential flooding during monsoon season.
instructions: Check weather forecasts regularly during monsoon season.
Keep emergency supplies including food, water, and medications ready.
Avoid walking or driving through flooded areas and waterlogged streets.
Keep important documents in waterproof containers.
Clear drains and gutters around your property to prevent waterlogging.
Have alternative lighting sources ready in case of power outages.
Stay informed about local flood warnings and evacuation orders.
Keep emergency contact numbers handy including local authorities.

heat stroke.summary: Immediate cooling and medical attention required for heat-related illness.
instructions: Move the person to a cool, shaded area immediately.
Remove excess clothing and apply cool, wet cloths to the skin.
Fan the person and apply ice packs to armpits, neck, and groin areas.
Give cool water to drink if the person is conscious and able to swallow.
Do not give alcohol or caffeinated beverages.
Call emergency services at 102 for ambulance immediately.
Monitor the person's breathing and pulse until help arrives.
If unconscious, place in recovery position and monitor vital signs.
